title: CM: Govt committed to welfare of elderly
text:
Tribune News Service
Dehradun, October 1
Chief Minister Harish Rawat, while addressing a gathering at a function held on International Day of Older Person today, reiterated his government's commitment towards forming a state policy for senior citizens. The event was organised by HelpAge India. He said a programme to provide free optical care to the needy elderly across the state was being charted out by the Health Deportment. The Chief Minister said some roads and streets in the city should be reserved for senior citizens so that they could walk freely. Former Mussoorie MLA Jot Singh Gunsola said elderly people with their wisdom and knowledge could guide the younger generation. Mayor Vinod Chamoli said senior citizens should be respected. Earlier, GC Pant IG, Telecom, and TK Hazarika, GM, NABARD, Uttarakhand chapter, flagged off a walk-a-thon. Participants of all age groups formed a human chain to spread awareness. Students of Sanskar International and Govt Middle School, Rajpur Road, were special participants. Youngsters tied 'Hug' (Help unite generations) bands to senior citizens to show their love and affection towards them. A seminar on “Senior citizens in Uttarakhand: Challenges and opportunities” was organised at Town Hall. SK Shukla, a former IPS officer, said senior citizens should pay special attention to their physical and financial security and should not transfer the title of their property to the next generation. So that, in the time of need, the property can be mortgaged to fulfill their financial requirements in old age. Aapga Singh, programme organiser, HelpAge India, said if all senior citizens get united they would be strongest group in society.
